content.description: Start 4' to the right of the plastered crack.   Climb upward until you're roughly bridge level then start going right.
content.protection: If bouldering 3 pads and 2 people. One person to spot, the other to adjust pads.   If trad climbing bring roughly 3 small sized cams.

content.description: You can choose to boulder to the top or top rope.
content.protection: Pads, anchors are at the top but they look pretty old and rusty.
content.location: Once at the top you can walk down a steep hill, or repel.

content.description:
The moves on this problem are not as repetitive as chalk dust.  

  Named after Kevin falling onto his unopened coconut water, causing it to spray and soak the pad.
content.protection: 1 pad, double stack pads if your passing the arc.

content.description: Don't let the mortar cracks fool you.    There's a good grove for crimping every 2 stone layers. Not every stone layer.   This bridge support has been sprayed with a glaze coating to help prevent weathering. This is bad because it makes some spots smooth, this is also good because the route might be to easy without it.   Named after Kevin fell from the arc onto his chalk bucket that contained loose chalk. His face was powdery.
content.protection: 1 pad will do if your climbing to the arc. If your going past the arc you will need to double stack your mats.

content.description: This small area is packed full of problems on both the East & West Side of the river.    -The railroad bridge have spots to boulder, sport climb, and top rope   - The Stearns road bridge has 8-12 Routes
